articles.title: Climate 'lies' claim misrepresents Antarctic sea ice loss
articles.summary: A Facebook post claims Antarctic sea ice extent is 17% higher today than it was in 1979. Long-term data is needed to understand trends in Antarctica sea ice, experts say. The data is for five-day average to smooth out day-to-day variability. There was little change in the Antarctic until the last decade.

articles.title: "Environmental Pollution and Global Warming" exhibition held in Iraq
articles.author: 新华网
articles.summary: People attend "Environmental Pollution and Global Warming" exhibition held at Iraq's Ministry of Culture, Tourism, and Antiquities in Baghdad, Iraq, on Feb. 5, 2025, at the exhibition of the Ministry's "Environmental and Global warming" theme.

articles.title: GLOBAL TEMPERATURES COOL SIGNIFICANTLY IN JANUARY; RECORD SNOWS PERSIST IN JAPAN; NO SEA-LEVEL RISE SINCE 1800s; BLIZZARDS ON SAKHALIN; + FINLAND NEARS -40C (-40F) – The planet has cooled 0.5C in 10 months.
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: The planet has cooled by 0.5C in 10 months. There was a record snowfall in Japan and blizzards on Sakhalin. Finland is near -40C and there was no sea-level rise for the first time since 1800s.

articles.title: Enormous ice area in Arctic disappears, equivalent to six times the size of Wales.
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice extent has dropped to its second lowest extent for January. This is due to abnormally warm temperatures which have prevented ice from forming properly over the winter. Since 1979, the Arctic has lost 726,000 square miles (1.88 million square kilometres) of sea ice.

articles.title: Global bird-watching event coming to Brownsville
articles.summary: The Great Backyard Bird Count is coming to Brownsville this month. The global birding event will begin on Friday, February 14 and end on Monday, February 17. Residents can choose to count birds from home, a local park, or the Resaca de la Palma State Park.

articles.title: Bird flu is taking a massive toll on wild animals, researchers find
articles.summary: Researchers are reporting mass die offs of wild birds and sea mammals due to bird flu. They're tracking the deaths to better understand the virus and how it might create a greater threat to humans. On KPBX 91.1, KPBZ 90.3 PRX Remix, and KSFC 91.9.

articles.title: Top yet contested climate scientist declares 2C climate goal 'dead'
articles.summary: Hansen and co-authors argue that Earth's climate is more sensitive to rising greenhouse gas emissions than previously thought. The amount of greenhouse gases already pumped into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels means increased warming is now guaranteed. The world's nations agreed during the landmark Paris climate accord of 2015 to try to hold end-of-century warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Top yet contested climate scientist declares 2C climate goal 'dead'
articles.author: Issam AHMED
articles.summary: Holding long-term global warming to two degrees Celsius is now impossible, according to a new analysis published by leading scientists. The paper appears in the journal "Environment: Science and Policy for Sustainable Development" and concludes that Earth's climate is more sensitive to rising greenhouse gas emissions than previously thought.

articles.title: Migratory birds leave Terai early as temp 4°C up in Feb than last yr
articles.author: TNN
articles.summary: Temperatures in the Terai region of Uttarakhand have risen too high for migratory birds. The birds usually arrive from Europe and Central Asia in November and stay until March. This year, the birds stayed for just three months instead of the usual four. Environmental activist Rajiv Nayan voiced concerns over shifting trends in migration.

articles.title: Storm warning: Labor-market consultant compares coming demographic shifts to hurricane coming ashore
articles.author: Business Journal
articles.summary: Economic-development wins raise competition for workers in Greensboro. Consultant warns of a hurricane-level storm on the way, which will be worse than what Greensboro has seen to this point in the last few years, and warns of pain in the past couple of years.

articles.title: How to help stop bird flu and salmonella spreading at feeders, backyard poultry cages
articles.author: Jessica Skropanic
articles.summary: Migrating birds can help spread H5N1 bird flu and other diseases among other bird species, animals and occasionally people. Feeders, bird baths and backyard poultry enclosures can be sources of salmonella and bird flu. Good practices include disinfecting places birds frequent, removing feeders during spikes in outbreaks and practicing good hygiene habits.

articles.title: Phuket named 3rd best winter sun destination
articles.summary: Phuket has been crowned the third best winter sun destination, according to Bounce. It earned a winter sun score of 6.24 out of 10, while Darwin and Sydney are No.1 and No.2. In winter, Phuket experiences the dry season, running from December to February. There is a daily average of eight hours of sunshine and temperatures average 27C.

articles.title: Gender equality is crucial for a climate resilient future, say researchers
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: IIASA study shows why gender equality trends should be central to planning how societies adapt to and mitigate climate change. A new study by IIASA shows that gender equality should be a key consideration in planning how society adapts to and mitigated climate change, as well as in planning for the future of society.

articles.title: Extreme cold warning rescinded
articles.author: Tanner Smith
articles.summary: The extreme cold warning for the Peace Region and much of Alberta has been rescinded. Grande Prairie was the coldest place on Earth on Tuesday, February 4, at 9 a.m., with a temperature of minus 39 and minus 44 with the windchill. The city's coldest temperature record was set in 1950 at minus 50.

articles.title: Okaloosa County wants residents' opinion on Flood Vulnerability Assessment Project
articles.author: Eleonora Newell
articles.summary: The second public meeting for the Flood Vulnerability Assessment Project is on Monday, February 10 from 5:30 to 7 p.m. at Okaloosa County Administrative Building Training Room, 1250 Eglin Parkway in Shalimar. The project is aimed at protecting the unincorporated areas of the county against environmental risks, which include rising sea levels and flooding.

articles.title: Africa's shifting migration patterns and new challenges to watch in 2025 — ACSS report
articles.author: North Africa Post
articles.summary: Report by the Africa Center for Strategic Studies (ACSSS) highlights the need for regional cooperation to accommodate intra-continental population movements in Africa in 2025. Africa's youthful population, with over 60% of its population being under 25, will be key destinations for African students and professionals looking for opportunities.

articles.title: From green to grey
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Pakistan has experienced a noticeable reduction in rainfall and a deteriorating Air Quality Index (AQI), especially during winters. This is due to deforestation, ever expanding housing schemes, and increased deforestation.    in recent years, Pakistan has also experienced a decrease in rainfall.

articles.title: Residents asked to play part in 2025 ‘Backyard Bird Count' next week
articles.author: ARLnow.com
articles.summary: The 2025 Great Backyard Bird Count takes place from Friday, February 14 to Monday, February 17. The observations that result will help scientists better understand global bird migrations. It was launched in 1998 by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology and National Audubon Society. It expanded to Canada in 2009 and went global in 2013.

articles.title: NASA's Asteroid Bennu Could Cause A Global Catastrophe, Scientists Say
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Bennu's highly unlikely impact with Earth could cause a global winter and drought. Bennu's impact could happen in 157 years, which could cause the drought and winter, according to modeling.   Â. Â   y   in

articles.title: Daily Mail's AI-Generated Climate Apocalypse Not Backed By Science, Data
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: A recent post at Daily Mail uses AI to create apocalyptic pictures of what the world will look like in 2100 due to climate change. The AI-generated images are entertaining but lack a basis in solid evidence or data. The article hypes the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) models predicting future warming.

articles.title: Indonesia to try to curb effects of rising seas with huge wall
articles.summary: Indonesia plans to build a 700 km long coastal wall to protect the rice fields of the northern coast of the island of Java from rising sea levels. The construction could take one to two decades and will be integrated with existing flood and tide control dykes.

articles.title: Over 20,000 birds winter at Indawgyi Lake in Myanmar
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: More than 20,000 birds from 46 species have taken refuge this winter at Indawgyi Lake in northern Myanmar's Kachin State. This year's wintering bird census was conducted in the first week of January, the peak period for migratory birds at the lake and its surrounding areas. The U.N. designated the lake a Man and the Biosphere Reserve in June 2017.

articles.title: Why CO₂ Cannot Explain Current Warming
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: For decades, the dominant climate narrative has been that rising carbon dioxide levels are the primary driver of global warming. But the last interglacial period, the Eemian, was significantly warmer than today, despite CO₂ levels being much lower. This contradiction highlights fundamental flaws in the assumptions underpinning climate modeling.

articles.title: Dismantling NOAA Would Break Lifesaving Weather and Climate Data and Tools People in US Rely on Daily
articles.author: Union
articles.summary: Elon Musk and his 'DOGE' group want to dismantle the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Yesterday, they illegally entered NOAA's Maryland headquarters, bypassing security and seized internal systems. NOAA provides lifesaving information that aids in forecasting U.S. weather and climate extremes. It is used by the public, local and state governments, emergency responders, and the private sector. The Project 2025 manifesto calls for dismantling NOAA and commercializing its forecasting work.

articles.title: Why do we keep putting our kids in harm's way?
articles.summary: After the pandemic, the response to COVID-19 was an intergenerational welfare transfer. Climate change is likely doing the same thing to young people. Two-thirds of schools in Australia are in the highest risk areas when it comes to climate change. The biggest risks are bushfire and hail. By 2060, the number of high-risk schools will increase from two-thirds to more than 84 per cent.

articles.title: Surviving Australia's Scorching Heat: Tips for Beating the Summer Sun
articles.author: Atta Ur Rehman
articles.summary: Summer temperatures in Australia can reach up to 40°C (104°F), challenging even the most prepared people. Understanding the science behind this searing heat is essential for safe, enjoyable summers in Australia, as it is for the safety of people and the environment.

articles.title: Area school closures, delays for Thursday, Feb. 6.
articles.author: Cumberland Times-News
articles.summary: Allegany College of Maryland will open at 11 a.m. on Thursday, February 6, 2025, due to inclement weather. All other school districts and colleges will be open as usual on that day due to weather-related changes.

articles.title: Australian Migration Views: Majority Oppose High Intake
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Majority of Australians view current migration levels as excessive. 57.6% of respondents want no change or an increase in Australia's international student intake. 75% of migrant arrivals in 2022-23 were on temporary visas, including 283,000 international students. India was the most prominent country of birth for arrivals.

articles.title: Resilient SRQ holding community survey for future hurricane preps
articles.author: ABC7 Staff
articles.summary: Sarasota County is launching a 'Resilient SRQ Unmet Needs Survey' The responses will help officials allocate resources for victims of future hurricanes. A meeting is being held tonight at 5:30 p.m. to 7:30 pm at the Frances T. Bourne Jacaranda Public Library in Venice. There will be future meetings on Feb. 8, 13, and 15 in Sarasota.

articles.title: Seasonal Climate prediction will boost food security, says agric minister
articles.author: Stella Odueme
articles.summary: The timely release of Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) will ensure that Nigerian farmers are well informed in decision-making and agricultural planning, thereby enhancing their productivity. Sen. Aliyu Sabi Abdullahi made this known during a meeting with the Minister for Agriculture and Food Security.

articles.title: New AI-powered early warning system to combat climate-induced disasters in KZN
articles.author: Independent online
articles.summary: In an era where climate change poses an increasing threat to communities worldwide, a groundbreaking initiative is taking shape in South Africa. The collaborative effort involved the University of the West of Scotland (UWS), the University and the South African Meteorological Agency. It would focus on rain and flooding and predict disease symptoms outbreak.

articles.title: Arctic sea ice is at its second lowest on record, scientists warn
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice extent has dropped to its second lowest extent for January. It is 300,000 square miles lower than the average for January 2024. Since 1979, the Arctic has lost 726,000 sq miles (1.88 million sq km) of sea ice. Antarctic sea ice extents have also dropped to near record lows.

articles.title: Scientist says 2°C climate goal ‘dead'
articles.author: Taipei Times
articles.summary: Holding long-term global warming to 2°C is an implausible scenario, according to the authors of the study published in an environment journal. They say that honesty is necessary for change.      .   in the study.

articles.title: Environment Canada cautions of frostbite as frigid temperatures linger in B.C.
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: Environment Canada cautions of frostbite and hypothermia as frigid conditions linger over much of British Columbia. Arctic air mass over central B.C. is bringing wind chills near -40 to the north and -20 in coastal areas and the Whistler Valley. Extreme cold warnings have also been issued for the Peace Region, including Fort St. John and Dawson Creek.

articles.title: Environment Canada cautions of frostbite as frigid temperatures linger in B.C.
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Environment Canada is warning of frostbite and hypothermia. Extreme cold and arctic outflow warnings are in place for much of British Columbia. People are advised to limit outdoor activities and keep pets and outdoor animals sheltered.  .

articles.title: You have been warned
articles.author: Ian Plimer
articles.summary: There are long-term consequences for misguided environmentalism. Fossil fuels, mining, industry and agriculture in Europe have been under relentless attack for decades. Many German cars are no longer made in Germany, almost all mines have closed and cows get a thorough thrashing.

articles.title: Breaking winter weather records
articles.author: Paul Dols
articles.summary: Jack Hamel and Kate Canty took a skate on White Bear Lake before sunset. The high of 52 degrees broke the previous record of 48 degrees set in 1989 and 1879. Temperatures are expected to return closer to average this week with a string of below freezing highs and lows predicted.

articles.title: 10 Regions Most at Risk from Climate Change by 2050
articles.author: B.Sc. Jessica Taylor
articles.summary: The Arctic is experiencing temperature increases at a pace that far surpasses the global average. In Sub-Saharan Africa, regions such as the Sahel and the Horn of Africa face relentless climate challenges. In South Asia, countries such as Indonesia, Philippines, Vietnam, Thailand, and Myanmar find themselves on a precarious edge due to escalating climate threats.

articles.title: Fighting climate change, one eco-club at a time
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu has seen extreme weather events due to climate change. Chief minister M K Stalin launched initiatives at the Climate Summit. The government will soon come out with a policy on climate education and eco-clubs will be set up in schools across the state.

articles.title: Malawi: UK Search and Rescue Experts Arrive to Train Malawian Counterparts
articles.author: Duncan Mlanjira
articles.summary: 12 search and rescue experts from the UK arrived in Malawi today. They will train their Malawian counterparts on how to respond to future floods and build Malawi's resilience to climate change-induced severe weather events. The training will target SAR strategic planners and boat operators and culminate in a live simulation exercise on Lake Malawi on February 9-10.

articles.title: 'Point of no return' collapse of Atlantic current could see UK temperatures plummet
articles.author: Rob Waugh
articles.summary: Professor James Hansen has warned that climate change could affect the Atlantic Meridional overturning circulation (AMOC), a system of ocean currents in the Atlantic. The AMOC is one of the reasons Britain and Europe are relatively warm compared to parts of the USA and Canada. An abrupt shift could leave Britain 3.5C cooler and unable to grow many crops.

articles.title: Scientists discover skull of oldest known modern bird
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: The fossilized skull of the oldest known modern bird has been discovered. The early relatives of ducks and geese lived in Antarctica at around the same time Tyrannosaurus rex dominated North America, say scientists. It is 69-million-years-old.

articles.title: Trump adding to 'acute' energy challenges in Australia
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Trump administration's early action on deregulation and energy investment add to "acute" challenges facing Australian producers, according to the Australian Chamber of Commerce of Australia and New Zealand (ACNWA)    “Deregulation” and “energy investment” add to “acute” challenges for Australian producers.

articles.title: Peru's shrimp, tilapia exports, production plummet, but scallop boom sparks hope
articles.summary: Peru's aquaculture sector faced a challenging year in 2024, with a decline in production attributed to adverse climatic conditions. María Feijóo reports this to Alex E. Proimos on February 5, 2025 at 16:29 GMT.

articles.title: Arctic sea ice is at its second lowest level on RECORD - missing an area 60 times the six of Wales, scientists warn
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice extent is down 498,000 square miles (1.29 million square kilometres) compared to the 1981 to 2010 average. The Arctic is missing an area of ice six times the size of Wales. Warm temperatures have prevented ice from forming properly over the winter. Since 1979, the Arctic has lost 726,000 sq miles of sea ice.

articles.title: Snow geese fill Northern California skies as majestic birds start migration back north
articles.author: Clifford Oto
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of snow geese return to California's wetlands every winter. The Central Valley is part of the Pacific Flyway, a major north-south path for migratory birds. Millions of birds use the flyway to move southward during winter and back north as the weather warms up.

articles.title: Temperatures at North Pole 20C Above Average and Beyond Ice Melting Point
articles.author: Slashdot
articles.summary: Temperatures at the north pole soared more than 20C above average on Sunday, crossing the threshold for ice to melt. Burning fossil fuels has heated the planet by about 1.3C since preindustrial times. The poles are warming faster as reflective sea ice melts.

articles.title: How South Africa's Mediterranean Climate Shapes Its Agricultural Practices
articles.author: Atta Ur Rehman
articles.summary: South Africa is renowned for its diverse climatic regions. The Mediterranean climate is found predominantly in the southwestern part of the country. Mediterranean climate influences crop selection, farming methods, and economic outputs in agriculture. It is characterized by wet winters and dry, hot summers.

articles.title: Bird sickness appears ‘contained'
articles.author: Shaw
articles.summary: Niwa data shows Dunedin had 256 hours of sunshine last month. It was the third-sunniest January on record in Dunedin.       in Niwa data.  In January it was cooler than average, but it was still sunny.

articles.title: City basked in sunshine despite chillier temperatures
articles.author: John Lewis
articles.summary: It was the third-sunniest January on record in Dunedin. It was cooler than average in Invercargill and more sunny in Hokitika than Christchurch and Wellington. January was a dry month for many parts of the country, particularly for the West Coast, Southland and southern and inland Otago.

articles.title: Greater Victoria classes in session; Malahat sees 35 cm snow in 2 days
articles.summary: Flurries are expected to continue in Greater Victoria. The Malahat airport had 35 cm of snow, while Victoria International airport saw 10 cm. The airport in North Saanich had the least amount of snow. Victoria opened a warming centre at the start of the snow squalls.

articles.title: Greater Victoria classes in session; Malahat sees 35 cm snow in 2 days
articles.author: Christine van Reeuwyk
articles.summary: Flurries are expected to continue in Greater Victoria. Malahat airport had 35 cm of snow, while Victoria International airport saw 10 cm. North Saanich airport had the least amount of snow. About 35 cm fell at Nanaimo airport, Shawnigan Lake 29 cm, north Courtenay 24 cm, Campbell River airport 20 cm, North Cowchan 18 cm, Tofino 16 cm, Qualicum Beach and Comox 14 cm.

articles.title: A huge luxury home is about to fall into the sea and nobody knows what to do with it
articles.author: Andre Muggiati
articles.summary: The house overlooking Cape Cod Bay is teetering on the brink of collapse due to coastal erosion exacerbated by climate change. The previous owner dismantled the deck and a bedroom tower before halting further work and entering a dispute with the town. The property has since been sold to a salvage company unwilling to finance its demolition. Wellfleet officials are concerned about the potential environmental consequences of the house's collapse.

articles.title: Niger-Delta stakeholders move to protect, restore regions mangroves
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Environment stakeholders from the nine states of the Niger Delta have convened to address climate change and its effects on the region. The meeting convened by the National Council on Climate Change Secretariat in Calabar on Tuesday identified ways of restoring, conserving, and protecting the nations mangrove ecosystems.

articles.title: I'm a 3rd-generation Floridian. I left at 18 and don't plan to live in the state again — especially because I have kids.
articles.author: Tiffany Nieslanik
articles.summary: As a third-generation Floridian, she can't see herself moving back to Florida with her family. She left South Florida three weeks after her 18th birthday. She joined the Army out of high school in 1995 and lived in several states before settling in Colorado with her spouse and three children. She's not aligned with the state's view on education or climate change.

articles.title: Pakistan's agriculture feels heat of winter drought
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: A lack of rainfall this winter is taking a significant toll on Pakistan's agricultural. Experts warn that climate change and other factors could jeopardize Pakistan's future food security. Pakistan's winter rainfall is usually good or even in surplus when the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) index is in its positive phase. It's significantly lower when the NAO index is negative.

articles.title: MOWCA strengthens collaboration with NiMET to enhance Maritime safety
articles.author: Daily Times
articles.summary: MOWCA has reaffirmed its commitment to leveraging climate prediction for safer navigation across the region. Secretary General Dr. Paul Adalikwu emphasized this collaboration at the Nigerian Meteorological Agency (NiMET) Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) event in Abuja.

articles.title: Florida strawberry growers battle Arctic cold to protect Valentine's Day harvest
articles.summary: Plant City-Dover is the "Winter Strawberry Capital of the Nation". It has over 13,000 acres of strawberries, which contribute nearly 15% of the U.S. supply during winter. The recent Arctic air outbreaks threaten these crops. The economic stakes are high as strawberry value has surged over the last two decades.

articles.title: Climate-conscious Europe braces for fossil-fuelled Trump 2.0
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Donald Trump's return to the White House signals a sharp U-turn on US climate policy. Trump's policies could slow global decarbonisation efforts and embolden fossil fuel interests. Trump is framing his climate rollback as a fight against 'climate extremism', echoing the language of far-right European parties. Some of Trump's more radical moves could face legal and congressional pushback.

articles.title: Climate Facts: Greenland's ice sheet cracking rapidly due to global warming
articles.author: Janefrances Chibundu
articles.summary: Climate change will eliminate about $1.47 trillion in US home values over the next three decades and hasten economic gaps in US communities. Climate-driven weather is expected to hike US homeowners' insurance premiums nationwide by an average of 29.4 percent by 2055. UNICEF says 2.2 million Nigerian students experienced school disruptions due to flooding in 2024.

articles.title: HUMBOLDT LIFE: Meet Larus hyperboreus, the Glaucous Gull!
articles.summary: The glaucous gull (Larus hyperboreus) is the second largest gull in the world. It breeds in Arctic regions of the Northern Hemisphere and winters south to shores of the Holarctic. The genus name is from Latin Larus and the specific name is Latin for Northern.

articles.title: Liberia: EPA Celebrates World Wetlands Day 2025, Calls for Stronger Protection Measures
articles.author: Contributor
articles.summary: The Environmental Protection Agency of Liberia has celebrated World Wetlands Day 2025 in Marshall City, Margibi County. The event aimed to raise awareness about the critical role wetlands play in environmental conservation and economic activities such as fishing, farming, and tourism. President Joseph Nyuma Boakai issued a Presidential Proclamation declaring February 3, 2025, as World Wetland Day in Liberia. Liberia is a signatory to the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands.

articles.title: Wexford walking trail in danger of being lost after ‘shocking' erosion during Storm Éowyn
articles.author: Isabel Colleran
articles.summary: Courtown Community Council is responsible for monitoring the Courtown-Kiltennel Walking Trail. They have been conducting annual coast-watch surveys in association with coastwatch.org for the last five years. Since they began their surveys five years ago, they've seen an ongoing loss in this area of one to two metres per year.

articles.title: The CO2 Hoax, ChatGPT, and God. Disinformation Tools of the Technocracy
articles.author: Reality Books
articles.summary: ChatGPT is a non-living computer program that answers questions from prompts and answers them in a misleading way. In the book CO2 Climate Hoax, Richard Moss claims that over 1900 scientists and climate professionals have refuted the UN IPCC's claim that climate change is caused by CO 2 emissions.

articles.title: Hunters in the Snow
articles.author: Kellyn Brown
articles.summary: There are a lot of Canada geese and cranes in the area. Southern California is starting to get some rain. The New York Times has a new gimmick, the '10-Minute Challenge' in which you spend 10 minutes contemplating a work of art.

articles.title: Extreme heat: Where 50C temperatures could hit this week
articles.summary: A band of intense heat is making its way across the country this week. The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a heatwave warning for WA. Severe heat warnings have been issued for the Kimberley, Pilbara, Gascoyne, Goldfields, South Interior and Central Wheat Belt Districts. Weatherzone predicts that temperatures could hit 50C in parts of WA this week, with Friday 7 February bringing particularly intense heat.

articles.title: Letters to the editor: Stop rollback of climate legislation; Neguse should work to end war; population growth is unsustainable
articles.author: Daily Camera letters
articles.summary: The recent Los Angeles fires were made more likely by climate change. The current administration is trying to freeze federal funding and repeal the Inflation Reduction Act. We need to preserve the progress that was made and continue our efforts to protect our homes and the planet.

articles.title: Should Humans Intervene to Save Species from Extinction or Let Nature Take Its Course?
articles.author: Trizzy Orozco
articles.summary: The rate of species extinction has grown exponentially due to human activities. The ethical implications of human intervention in natural processes are discussed in the book "The Ethical Implications of Species Extinction" by David Frum and David Kosten.    "Should humans intervene to prevent species extinction?

articles.title: Fact Check: Post Suggesting UK's Contribution To Climate Change Is Negligible Is Misleading
articles.author: Telugu Post
articles.summary: UK has emitted so much greenhouse gas since the start of the Industrial Revolution that its historical emissions are still accumulated in the atmosphere today. Most of the world's greenhouse gas emissions come from a relatively small number of countries. China, United States and nations of the European Union are the largest emitters.

articles.title: Why temperatures at north pole reached 20 degrees Celsius above average
articles.author: Alind Chauhan
articles.summary: Temperatures increased by more than 20 degrees Celsius above average at the north pole on February 2. Since 1979, the Arctic has warmed four times faster than the global average. The current unusually mild temperatures in the region were due to a deep low-pressure system over Iceland.

articles.title: Defiant Stance: Gazans Reject Trump's 'Riviera' Vision
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Gazans are opposed to U.S. President Donald Trump's proposal to transform the Gaza Strip into a 'Riviera of the Middle East'. They fear a potential repeat of the 1948 'Nakba' displacement, emphasizing the importance of teaching their children about steadfastness.

articles.title: Can world football tackle its growing emissions bootprint?
articles.summary: Football is at risk of falling to the bottom of the league table unless serious climate action is taken to fight against climate change. The long-term future of the sport faces significant risks if it does not take steps to combat climate change in the long-run.

articles.title: The Climate Change HOAX
articles.author: Administrator
articles.summary: There is no evidence of global warming. The English Court ruled against Al Gore and his climate film. The data from New York City with records back to 1869 shows a normal climate cycle. The computer warns that we are headed into colder weather and a rise in volcanic activity.

articles.title: Scientists target 13 danger zone locations at extreme risk for future damage: 'It's a losing battle'
articles.author: Jenny Allison
articles.summary: Some of the world's busiest oil ports are at risk of being damaged by rising sea levels due to the use of fossil fuels. The rate of sea level rise has already doubled in the last 30 years. Scientists urge transitioning away from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources.

articles.title: Majority of Australians believe migration too high, oppose cutting student intake: survey
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: 52.9% of Australians think the country's migrant intake is too high. 57.6% oppose cutting international student numbers. Immigration is expected to be a major policy issue in Australia's general election, which must be held by May. Of the 554,000 migrant arrivals in 2022-23, 75% were on temporary visas, including 283,000 international students.

articles.title: Is climate change speeding up? James Hansen took a look.
articles.author: Chelsea Harvey
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement's 1.5 Celsius target has already been breached. Even the 2 C target may be out of reach. A cascading series of global tipping points, from collapsing ice sheets to catastrophic sea-level rise may already be imminent. James Hansen has spent the last four decades warning about global warming.

articles.title: Scientists issue dire warning after analyzing data from 2024: '[It] will … become more frequent, intense, and deadly'
articles.author: Chelsea Cook
articles.summary: Last year's extreme weather caused more than 3,700 deaths and displaced millions of people. Scientists warn that we're getting close to the 1.5 degrees Celsius warming limit set by the Paris Agreement. With urgent and sustained action, we can reduce the risks and work toward a more resilient future.

articles.title: Race on to stop climate destroying our health
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: The World Economic Forum has released a report on the human and economic impacts of climate change on 11 diseases, including malaria, dengue fever and cholera. It is estimated that climate change will cause 14.5 million deaths and US$ 12.5 trillion in economic costs by 2050 and 500 million more people will be exposed to vector-borne diseases. Low-resource countries will bear the brunt of negative health effects.

articles.title: On Today's Date: Antarctica's Record High; World's Coldest Town Record Low
articles.author: Jonathan Erdman
articles.summary: On February 6, 2020, Antarctica set its all-time record high of 64.9 degrees Celsius at Esperanza Base, an Argentine research station near the northernmost tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. On Feb. 6, 1933, 92 years ago, in Oymyakon, Russia, the world's coldest temperature was recorded.

articles.title: Majority of Australians believe migration too high, oppose cutting student intake: survey
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: 52.9 percent of Australians believe immigration to the country is too high. 57.6 percent oppose cutting international student numbers. 4.5 percent say the country should accept more immigrants. Immigration is expected to be a major policy issue in Australia's general election, which must be held by May.

articles.title: Half-Degree Warming to Triple Uninhabitable Earth Zones

articles.title: Woodland bird populations in Scotland increase by over 50 per cent
articles.author: Craig Williams
articles.summary: Woodland birds have seen the largest indicator increase of over 50%. Chiffchaff numbers have increased 1428%, great spotted woodpeckers by 699%, and blackcap by 593%. Upland birds have shown the largest declines (-20%). There has been an increase of 14% for urban bird species since 1994.

articles.title: Ice Causes Damage to Bell Sites Along North Coast of Labrador
articles.author: Sara Strickland
articles.summary: Some phone and communications services on the north coast of Labrador may be affected by ice damage caused to microwave tower equipment. Crews reported severe ice damage to the newly installed antenna equipment on three separate towers. The damage was caused to sites in remote and high elevation areas that are only accessible by helicopter. Bell hopes to get to the affected sites as soon as possible weather permitting.

articles.title: Global warming to triple area too hot even for young adults, South Asia most at risk: Study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Under continued global warming, the extent of land where healthy, young adults find it hard to adapt to rising heat could triple. South Asia is among the regions most at risk. Elderly people, aged 60 years and above, are more vulnerable to extreme heat due to age-related changes in their bodies.

articles.title: Trump's success and COP's failures have placed us firmly on the ‘highway to climate hell'
articles.author: Guillem Rius Taberner

Under current emission reduction policies, we can expect an increase of 3.1C above preindustrial levels by 2100. Fossil fuel burning is the main cause of global warming. The most recent COP29, held in Baku, Azerbaijan, ended with an underwhelming commitment to mobilise $300 billion annually by 2035 to finance developing countries' climate adaptation and mitigation.

articles.summary: Even healthy young humans would struggle to maintain a safe body temperature if we hit 2°C above preindustrial levels, according to a new study. Large areas of the planet may become too hot to be habitable during extreme heat events, as the study suggests.

articles.summary: 2023 and 2024 were the warmest years in Dutch history since measurements began in 1901. The country is heating up at a rate of 0.4 degrees Celsius per decade. De Bilt, near Utrecht, recorded temperatures 2.9 degrees Celsius higher than the overall average between 1901 and 1930. The global sea level has risen by 21 centimetres since the early 1900s.

articles.title: 74% of Latin American, Caribbean countries highly exposed to extreme weather events, affecting food security –new UN report shows
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: Climate variability and extreme weather events are negatively affecting all dimensions of food security and malnutrition in Latin America and the Caribbean, according to the 2024 Regional Overview of Food Security and Nutrition. The report highlights the urgent need to build resilience within agri-food systems. The region has made notable progress since the turn of the millennium but progress has slowed in recent years.

articles.title: Trump Taps 'Sharpiegate' Meteorologist, Neil Jacobs, To Lead Top US Science agency

articles.title: Earth is still warming even when we're freezing
articles.summary: Complaining that predictions about a warming Earth are not borne out with complete uniformity everywhere, all the time is childish logic. Climate problems will continue to worsen overall until we succeed in transitioning away from fossil fuels, writes Phoebe Barr from Brighton.

articles.title: Bushfire threat shuts down popular bushwalking trail
articles.summary: The Overland Track in Tasmania's World Heritage Wilderness Area has been closed for the next three days due to a significant bushfire. About 100 people are affected by the closure of the 65km, multi-day hiking trail.

articles.title: New Zealand's had its coldest January in nearly a decade

articles.summary: January 2025 was New Zealand's coldest January since 2017. The nationwide average temperature was 16.4°C, which is 0.8°C below the 1991-2020 January average.
